huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION:
Land Ownership: Moose habitat is primarily public land.

Population Objective: 500

Current Population Estimate: 350
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
ATTENTION-The US Forest is planning on a few prescribe burns this fall that might interfere with some hunters hunt. Please be aware. Salt Lake City, Utah, September 13, 2019 – Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Forest fire personnel plan to conduct a prescribed burn in the Sheep Creek area September 18, 2019 – November 30, 2019 when weather conditions allow.  The project area is located in Utah County, approximately 30 miles east southeast of Spanish Fork, Utah, and northwest of Soldier Summit from Highway 6.  The burn unit includes approximately 5,927 acres. This prescribed burn is part of a vegetation project that included mechanical treatment in 2013 through 2017.HWY 150
Upper Provo, approximately five miles east of Kamas on the north side of Hwy 150 (Mirror Lake HWY). between Upper Setting and Norway Flat roads. The burn area reaches to the top of the ridge above Shingle Creek. The burn window is sometime between September 1st and December 1st.
West Fork of the Duchesne drainage. Burn area is ten miles west of Hwy 35 near Hanna, Ut. Burning will be targeted on the south side of the river from the reservoir to Little West Fork. The burn extends from the river bottom to the ridge. The burn window is sometime between September 1st and December 1st. Here is a link to the USFS facebook page for more information.
https://www.facebook.com/US-Forest-Service-Uinta-Wasatch-Cache-National-Forest-147726224920736/
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightening, snow, wind and heat.  It is quite common on clear mornings for clouds to build through the morning and have thunderstorms in the afternoon.  Be very cautious of lightening while hunting on high ridges.  Early fall snow storms occur regularly in this area.  Most years the snow will melt off, within a day or two until through the first week on October.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 87.8~500~275~~~3.75–4.25~3.7~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Scouting Tips: Most moose are seen near rivers, streams, ponds, or lakes, focus your efforts near these areas. Later in the fall they will move into thick, brushy areas of oak brush and mahogany. Moose are very spread out on these subunits, so it is important to cover a lot of area. It is a great place to camp in the summer to scout and learn the roads and trails.

Behavior: As with most big game animals the early mornings and evenings are the best times to find moose. This is when most rutting activity will take place as well. Moose are typically a solitary animal, groups of bulls are uncommon until late fall and winter. Bull moose can, and will travel long distances during the rut in search of cows. This is important to know, because areas where you saw bulls in the summer might not be where they will be in the fall, however areas where you saw cows in the summer may be good places to find bulls during the rut.

Moose rut: There will typically be a little rutting activity starting middle of September, with the peak of the rut being the end of September through the middle of October. There should be rutting activity throughout the entire hunting season.

Areas to Hunt:
Recommended areas Currant Creek Subunit:
Currant Creek Drainage- This entire area is great for moose, timbered North slopes, large aspen stands, lots of ponds, creeks, streams, and lakes. Great access, camping, nice road, several different draws or canyons to hunt(Layout Canyon, Big Dry Hollow, Low Pass Creek, Race Track), can hold moose.
North Fork Deep Creek/Water Hollow- very few roads, great area for horseback hunts, land managed by UDWR, borders private land in many spots.
Wildcat WMA- UDWR land, borders private, lots of roads, highest density of moose on the subunit.
West Fork Duchesne- Big area, road access, limited ATV access, timbered North slopes, large aspen stands, lots of water.
Tabby Mountain WMA- the North slope is best, ponds on top, UDWR land, great for ATV’s.
Red Creek Drainage- Great area for moose, some private property, lots of SITLA property that is open for hunting, anywhere along the Red Creek is good for moose.
Strawberry River- The entire river corridor East of Strawberry Reservoir. Area is thick and can be difficult to spot moose. Primarily land managed by the UDWR
Recommended areas Avintaquin Subunit:
Reservation Ridge- Big area, road on the divide, great area for glassing, not as many moose as Currant Creek.
Strawberry Peak Area- Highest peak on Avintaquin, great access to roadless areas(Slab Canyon and Cow Hollow), not a lot of moose in these areas.
Long Ridge- Great glassing area, areas South of Long Ridge along creeks and near ponds. Not a high density area.
Recommended areas Wasatch West Subunit:
American Fork Canyon- The canyon road takes you from the mouth of AF canyon east to Heber City. This area has a lot of moose. Look around Casacade Springs area.
Strawberry Reservoir- Look along all streams feeding into Strawberry Reservoir, such as Strawberry River, Coop Creek, Mud Creek and Indian Creek and Trout Creek. These areas are not a high density area.
Salt Lake County- All canyons on the east side of the valley have moose in them, such as Big and Little Cottonwood Canyons, Mill Creek, and Lambs Canyon. You can hunt with any weapon east on I-15 for OIAL hunts.
Other canyons to look in- Squaw Peak road, Right Hand Fork of Hobble Creek, Diamond Fork, Sheep Creek and Tie Fork. Not a lot of moose in these areas, but big bulls have been seen in the past.


Dollar Ridge Fire Update – July 2018

In early July 2018 the Dollar Ridge Fire burned approximately 50,000 acres on the Avintaquin and Currant Creek subunits of the Wasatch Mountains unit. The fire started in the Strawberry River Corridor and areas burned include portions of the Strawberry River wildlife management area and the Wildcat wildlife management area. Wildfire can have both negative and positive consequences for habitat and wildlife. In the right circumstances, wildfire can be a very effective tool for improving wildlife habitat. At lower elevation winter ranges fire may be detrimental if it removes important wintering feed sources or opens a niche for invasive weeds. In mid to high elevations fire often removes old, decadent growth and allows for new plants with high nutritional value. Grasses and forbs with high nutritional value are usually the first plant communities to come back after a fire. Regeneration in aspen stands is triggered by fire and mountain browse communities are quick to rebound.

This fire mostly occurred in higher summer and transition ranges for big game. Based on current burned locations, we anticipate the effects of the Dollar Ridge Fire to be mostly positive for deer, elk and moose. We have observed that GPS collared moose and elk in the burn temporarily moved to adjacent habitats while the fire was actively burning, then moved back almost immediately after the active fire subsided. If we receive our normal late-summer monsoon weather pattern it is very likely the burned areas will have a flush of new growth or “green-up” prior to the hunting season.

Wildfire can change wildlife distribution. Removal of cover may make an area less desirable for wary animals. Conversely, a good fall green-up might actually pull animals out of adjacent areas into the newly burned areas. Don’t overlook burned areas when hunting as they can be good places to locate game.

In 2017 the Brian Head fire burned 71,000 acres, nearly 25% of the Panguitch unit. At the end of the 2017 hunting season there were very few complaints from hunters and hunter success rates were normal to above normal. The Wasatch is a large unit and there are many locations with good hunting that were not affected by the Dollar Ridge Fire. We anticipate good opportunities for sportsmen this fall despite disturbance from the fire. In the long term we expect wildlife to reap many benefits from this fire.

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: click here or call 1-800-221-0659 to report your harvest. You must report your harvest, even if you did not take an animal, within 30 days of the season end date that is printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you not being able to apply for big game species in subsequent years. Submitting teeth or other biological samples from your animal, or having your animal checked by a DWR representative or CWMU operator does NOT fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement.

huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: All Campgrounds on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the Forest. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites. Avintaquin: http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley Currant Creek: http://www.fs.usda.gov/uwcnf Wasatch West: http://www.fs.usda.gov/uwcnf
huntBoundaryInfos.COUNTY_ROAD_INFO:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION Central Federal Lands Highway Division (CFLHD), in partnership with Wasatch County, Utah County, and the United States Forest Service (USFS) is planning to improve Strawberry Sheep Creek Road, a 31.9 mile route between US-6 and US-40. This road is really 
ROAD CLOSURE CONSIDERATIONS The key objective is to construct these roadway improvements while minimizing impacts to public users. To facilitate public safety, certain segments of the road will be closed during various construction activities. When the road is open, delays up to 30 minutes can be expected. The construction schedule is subject to change. During road closures, no motorized vehicles will be permitted on the route. Adjacent Off Highway Vehicle (OHV) trail routes will continue to be open during road closures. Where a potential conflict between an OHV and construction equipment is possible, the OHV access will be restricted for public safety. Emergency access will be permitted at all times.
ROAD CLOSURE PRELIMINARY SCHEDULE
a combination of three smaller routes, Sheep Creek – Rays Valley Road (FR 70051); Unicorn Ridge – Indian Creek Road (FR 70042); and West Side Strawberry Road (FR 70131). The construction work will be split into four segments: Segment 1 (FR 70051) begins at the MP 0.0 (intersection with US-6) and ends at MP 7.0 (FR 70042). The work on Segment 1 consists of pavement rehabilitation including patching, crack sealing, and chip sealing. Segment 2 and Segment 3 (FR 70042) begins at MP 7.0 and ends at FR 70131. The work on Segment 2 and 3 consists of roadway bench widening, paving, drainage improvements, and safety improvements. Segment 4 (FR 70131) begins at the intersection with FR 70042 and ends 3.75 miles north of the intersection. The work on Segment 4 consists of pavement rehabilitation, pulverizing, and paving with subexcavation as needed.
QUESTIONS? Wasatch County Public Works 1891 West 3000 South Heber City, Utah 84032 435-654-1661 www.wasatch.utah.gov
Utah County
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
Most roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service. Avintaquin: http://www.fs.usda.gov/ashley Currant Creek: http://www.fs.usda.gov/uwcnf Wasatch West: http://www.fs.usda.gov/uwcnf

There are also several roads and ATV trails on land managed by the Utah Division of Wildlife Resources. All vehicles and ATV’s must stay on designated roads and trails on these lands.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: Wasatch West, Currant Creek and Avintaquin subunits contain large amounts of Tribal Trust Lands. All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands and must be trailered on access roads across Tribal Lands.  For information on which roads are legal access roads contact Duchesne County. There are also several large areas of private land on both subunits, including 7 large CWMU’s. Hunters must receive written permission before hunting private lands. Wasatch Mountains OIAL moose permits are not valid on moose CWMU’s. There are 2 moose CWMU’s on the Currant Creek subunit (Moon’s Ranch and Little Red Creek), and 3 moose CWMU’s on the Wasatch West Subunit (Three C, Coyote/Little Pole and Wallsburg).
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Carbon, Duchesne, Emery, Juab, Millard, Salt Lake, Sanpete, Sevier, Summit, Utah and Wasatch counties—Boundary begins at the junction of I-15 and I-80 in Salt Lake City; east on I-80 to US-40; south on US-40 to SR-32; east on SR-32 to SR-35; southeast on SR-35 to SR-87; south on SR-87 to Duchesne and US-191; south on US-191 to US-6; southeast on US-6 to Price and SR-10; south on SR-10 to I-70; west on I-70 to US-50 at Salina; northwest on US-50 to I-15 at Scipio; north on I-15 to I-80 in Salt Lake City. EXCLUDING ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Delta, Duchesne, Huntington, Manti, Nephi, Price, Provo, Salina, Salt Lake City. Boundary questions? Call the Springville office, 801-491-5678; the Vernal office, 435-781-9453; or the Price office, 435-613-3700.
